description: During a series of “border battles” in the remote locations of Dak To, Con Thien and Khe Sanh, U.S. Army and Marines are relentlessly attacked by North Vietnamese Army.

The Tet Offensive begins, a combined assault by North Vietnamese Army and Viet Cong. Attacks are carried out in more than 100 cities and outposts across South Vietnam, including Hue and Saigon, and the U.S. Embassy is invaded.

Tet 1969 launched in February. These were attacks made by North Vietnamese Army in South Vietnam, one year after the original Tet Offensive. These attacks were all subdued but did inflict casualties and reinforced the fact that Viet Cong or North Vietnamese Army were able to mount attacks at will.

South Vietnamese troops attack Cambodia, particularly targeting Viet Cong bases. A U.S. force of 30,000 also joined the attack. Operations in Cambodia lasted for 60 days, and uncover vast North Vietnamese jungle supply depots.

In June, the Mansfield Amendment was adopted by Congress. The amendment urged withdrawing American troops from South Vietnam at "the earliest practical date"—the first time in U.S. history that Congress had called for the end of a war. Operation Jefferson Glenn in Thua-Thien Hue was the last major ground operation in which U.S. troops participated in the Vietnam War.
Only a third of U.S's troops remain. The ground war is now almost exclusively the responsibility of South Vietnam.

Ceasefire agreement is signed between U.S. and North Vietnam in January. In March, the last U.S soldiers leave Vietnam, though military advisors and some Marines who are protecting U.S. installations, remain.
